text: Patient: I can live with it if I can do the infusion stuff up there. Doctor: Okay. That's a possibility. However, as anything else, we actually have a study. Half the group gets regular chemo, which is IV. The other group gets a pill chemo which is oral. I can't tell you which one you are. And of course, we need you to commit so that if you say there's no freakin way I'm gonna get chemo down here then don't do the trial, but it's a fifty-fifty Family Member: You don't want to come down here xxx do you? Patient: How often do I have to be here? Doctor: Well, chemo is once every three weeks. So if you're good, don't quote me because I botched up a thousand things today in terms of the schedule, which is why I keep my mouth shut half the time. But standard chemo is once every three weeks. Family Member: Oh that’s not too bad. Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad. And the pill you take, there's a funky schedule but normally it's like, twice a day. But not every day. And there's a set schedule. You don't have to be here every day for that. But I think the follow up there is once every four weeks if I'm not wrong. Family Member: The pill isn't in the container? He has to come down here? Doctor: Well, we give it to you. But it's a funky formulation where, because you know, we do an oral formulation of the chemo is a challenge. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So this is like, there's a loading dose and then you have a little bit of another dose. So it's like, it's a pharma-pharmaco kinetics dream, who thought about it, which is not like a doctor dream, which is like, “just give me the pill in my pocket once a day.” I think eventually they're going to do that. But there is a funky schedule to it. None of which you have to be here, you know, the entire time. But I think in the first few- oh gosh, the first few days I think that you're here maybe for the first week every day. So, but I'll get the schedule right, but once you get on a flow, you're not here every day. Not even close. So it’s either once every three weeks, or once every four weeks. Patient: I can do it because obviously the Xtandi has run its course.

text: Patient: Just working zone. (Laughter) Doctor: How you feeling? Patient: I’ve been great. Doctor: The rest of your labs are fine, but, you know, your PSA is trickling up, four point two. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Now, in March, you were at two and a half. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I know that we want to be as aggressive as possible with you. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because sometimes when your disease decides to do something, we need to quiet it down quick. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: You had a shot in June. So your next one isn’t, you know, until September. Family Member: Right. Right.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process? Doctor: But we haven’t done the seeds, uh, we just do them alone. But we haven’t, you know, probably somebody’s going to try that concept, which is seeds and some kind of immunotherapy as well. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: There has been, uh, some trials where what they did is they took a patient who has spots in the bone and radiated one spot and give it immunotherapy. There’s some signal that the immunotherapy works better when you do that. Uh, that you’re sort of damaging the cells with radiation and that seems to get your own immune system- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum.

Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum.

text: Family Member: Um hum. DOC - then the best way to do that although it’s still not a cure is hormone therapy plus or minus something else. So something new. Doctor: Right, so there’s no question that hormone therapy within the first three months is going to kill like ninety-nine percent of the cancer. Happens with almost everyone. With radiotherapy you know there’s a decent chance that it’s going to kill whatever cancer happens to be part that we radiate – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - but the rest of the cancer which is going to be invisible is obviously going to be outside of that radiation field. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: It’s not going to be touched. And the concern with that is although I am a proponent of someone that wants to – If your goal is absolutely to avoid hormone therapy as long as possible, that’s a good option for you. And again, what would be driving that would be more quality of life. Patient: And that’s the um I guess that’s what’s (pause3secs) Healthcare Professional: Right, you just want to do what you have to, yes, exactly. No, we get that. Patient: Because I know there are so many side effects. Healthcare Professional: Right. Patient: So if where where the - we’re looking is probably radiation and sort of like not a complete hormone but like some sort of and I’m probably going to get some sort of a modified sense of a hormonal thing. So I’ll still have some effects of it, but in that effect so that the radiation if we do that part when we target it on what we know where it’s landed, the hormonal will be sort of be keeping everything else at bay at this point. Healthcare Professional: Right.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because that also would be a possibility, i.e., come off the trial, do some chemotherapy with the K___ oncologist, and then on the back end, when the chemotherapy is over, come back and do a different clinical trial at that point. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Okay. Okay. And, again, that’s one of the reasons why I wanted to come here, uh, uh, from the um perspective of the options. And, uh, and I, I, maybe I shouldn’t say this because your recorder is here, but I do like, not only the professionalism here, but, I, I like the sense of, uh, caring that the personnel here, uh, express. That’s from everybody within the building when you, when you come in. But the other thing is, when I come here to get lab work done, uh, I only get stuck one time. You know? I don’t like to be a big pincushion and you’ve gotten stuck four or five times, and the person still hasn’t hit the vein. Can I try your other arm? And I’m thinking like, come on, now. This, this reminds me of the time when I was in the Marine Corp. The corpsman do the stuff on purpose. You know? Doctor: Okay. Patient: So it is what it is. But I said that to say the quality of care and the compassion I can see here at J___ H___. I’m not saying it’s not there at K___. There’s some good doctors there, good personnel, that have been very helpful to me. Uh, but, uh, I see it all through the building here when I come here. That’s one thing. I could see it. Doctor: So are we all on the same page now? Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. text: Patient: I’m normal? Doctor: At least on your electrolytes, you are. And then your PSA has increased. Patient: Ah. Doctor: So last time it was 303. So 247, 303, and then today we have a measurement of 352. Patient: It’s getting worse and worse. Oh, well. Doctor: Have you ever had a bone scan before? Patient: No. Today I did. Doctor: So that was your first one ever? Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Okay. Okay. So because of your PSA going up, we checked scans. The bone scan tells us that, huh, you’ve got a lot of cancer in your bones. We sort of knew that from before even though we haven’t had a picture of that, and so, again, when they talk about what this looks like I have nothing to compare it to. Huh, but this is you, your body, these things here represent the cancer. So here’s your back bone, also a lot of it here in your ribs in multiple spots, a couple of areas on the skull bone that look like there’s cancer there, or one area in this, huh, your right, your left leg. Huh, huh, and then the CAT scan says, huh, that’s what we had used at the very beginning, huh, which says that basically all the areas in the bone that they saw before are still there, huh, with, huh, additional spots. Huh, and you’ve got some really small lymph nodes down in your pelvis. All that is doctor lingo for, huh, you know, you’ve had benefit from the hormone therapy, huh, but I really can’t tell you how much worse it is because these are the first real pictures since you’ve gotten started. You’re hanging in there, huh, but it would be, you know, time to change therapy. Family Member: Okay. We know. Patient: So what kind of pills can I take?

All that is doctor lingo for, huh, you know, you’ve had benefit from the hormone therapy, huh, but I really can’t tell you how much worse it is because these are the first real pictures since you’ve gotten started. You’re hanging in there, huh, but it would be, you know, time to change therapy. Family Member: Okay. We know. Patient: So what kind of pills can I take?

text: Patient: But if you’re not ready today I can get that back home too. Doctor: -bone weakness. Yeah you can. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: With a prescription. I was reading up on the prostate cancer in the bone and they recommended not – a diet low in calcium for that. Do you know anything about that? Doctor: No I think for a while people were maxing out and taking crazy high amounts of calcium. So that is not recommended because they actually found a worse outcome with that. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So the typical you don’t want to get past fifteen hundred a day. Family Member: Yeah they were saying that was too much. Doctor: For some reason that was the top – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - but yeah so no, no.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
